review_content: I was having problems with my wifi dropping out randomly, sometimes for a fraction of a second, sometimes completely (see photo). I looked at the reviews for them and saw an issue come up again and again in the reviews. People using those hubs had trouble transferring large files to/from external storage (thumb drives, external hard drives, etc). So I did an experiment. I plugged the new wifi into this hub, plugged the old wifi directly into the computer, and ran a continuous ping with each (one at a time, not both at once). Sure enough, the new one gave results that look like the photo, and the old one was smooth sailing, not a single return slower than 25ms. So clearly this hub was the culprit. I didn't seem to have this problem when I got it in March, and it started acting up in mid July. I'd give this 2 stars but people aren't going to buy a hub unless they're going to be transferring data (wifi, HD, flash keychain, etc) and even at this price range that's not something you want to have working when it feels like it.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2019
review_content: When I first plugged it in, my computer didn't appear to recognize it.  I went to device manager and it showed the hub, but everything said "unknown driver," which confused me because I thought it didn't need a driver.  I only know enough computer stuff to be dangerous, so I went to Sabrent's website and put in the hub model.  It showed no driver downloads, but had a pdf manual download.  The first line under trouble-shooting states, "To operate multiple hard drives and certain high power devices you may need a powered HUB most Sabrent HUBs can be turned into powered Hubs by adding a AC power adapter model PS-5V4A will work with most Sabrent Hubs look for a pin hole on the back of the HUB to verify if your model is compatible."  (Yes, they left out the ".'s") Sure enough, next to the computer cord on the hub is a pin hole.  I google'd the AC adapter and it looked just like the one that goes to the digital photo frame on my desk.  I plugged it in and wonders of wonders, it said it was installing drivers.  After it finished, I plugged in two USB drives and within a minute was transferring files.  (Transfer speed averaging around 7.7 MB/Second) One star off because I need to buy a power supply because I recently threw away all of my extra power adaptors to de-clutter my office.

If I plug more than 1 item in then nothing charges.Unfortunately I bought 2 of these and neither of them work, so I know it's not just the unit I have.  I would not recommend.

author: Vyse2k3
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2016
review_content: With my ever growing group of devices, I once again found myself in need of a new USB hub.  My needs were simple, I had no intention of connecting a hard drive or anything that would draw a significant amount of power, all I wanted to do was connect multiple input devices like keyboards, trackpads and gamepads.  I came across this Sabrent model with individual on/off switches for each port and liked that idea.This hub is inexpensive and has performed the function for which I needed it very well.  As is often the case, you do get what you pay for so this hub doesn't feel very solidly constructed and the lights above the ports kind of bleed over into adjacent ones and I ran into one minor issue with it where for a time it failed to recognize the trackpad on a keyboard/trackpad combination device.  It has worked flawlessly aside from that one hiccup.One thing to bear in mind if you plan to use this to connect external storage is that it is a USB 2.0 hub, so you will not get the best transfer speeds out of USB 3.0 devices.  Also, as this hub is not powered, you may need to run into some issues depending on the computer or whatever device to which this hub is connected.  I use it primarily on an NVIDIA Shield Android TV and have not run into that issue.  I have also briefly tested it on a couple of computers.If you have a need to connect simple devices without a significant power draw and would like the ability to enable or disable them at the touch of a button, this unit will fit the bill nicely and is easy on the wallet.  If you need a hub for storage devices or other devices that may need to draw more power from the host unit, you'll probably want to look into a powered hub instead.
title: A competent USB hub with indiviual power switches for its ports - ideal for connecting simple devices.

author: IMHO
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2018
review_content: This USB hub arrived promptly, in nice packaging, and it looks nice. I'm not sure how useful the illuminated On/Off switches are, but they don't hurt anything. The reason I only give it 3 stars is that the ports are too close together to allow me to use thumb drives. You can easily fit 4 ordinary USB plugs into the 4 slots. However, thumb drives are a little wider than an ordinary USB plug. Therefore, I have to free up 2 slots in order to use one thumb drive. Or free up all 4 slots to use 2 thumb drives. With just a little more thought, this could have been a tiny bit bigger so it could accommodate 4 thumb drives at once. Why not?
title: A little too small

author: David

review_content: I actually like this hub. It's nice to be able to turn the power on or off to each individual device that I'm charging. When I say "locking up" I mean that the mouse (also USB device plugged into another port) quits working until you shut off one of the charging ports on the hub.Is this the device's fault? I can't be sure if it's my computer or if it's because of the device. However, on the information provided from the seller there is no mention of this as a possibility to be aware of.The cord is very short and just barely long enough to put the port behind the laptop instead of having it sit on the keyboard.Perhaps a better solution would be to charge a battery pack and attach the hub to that pack to charge multiple devices? Maybe I'll give that a try.

review_content: i purchased this device for my Xbox One because with the stock hardware, its only possible to connect/charge one device at a time (cell phones, controllers, bluetooth devices, etc.). review_content: I bought this little hub 2 years ago because of its very informative reviews; it seemed very reliable for its cheap price. author: Matthew Steele
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2019
review_content: For some reason, Amazon's automated system seems to expect me to review this as a Camera. I can safely say that, while this is a highly effective 4-port USB charger, it fails in every respect as a camera.Looking at Amazon's feature list, the first thing it wants me rating is camera quality. I'm afraid I have to give this only a single star. If I could, I would give it even less. Forget megapixels, I was unable to use this alleged camera to get even a SINGLE pixel onscreen. I really have to question the decision-making of the manufacturer, seeing as they decided to forgo camera quality in favor of accessory features, like four LED USB ports which light up when charging, and thus allow me to easily manage power output to multiple devices.I must give it a 1 in charge power as well. Had I been expected to rate its capabilities at charging other objects, I would of course have given it a five star, the blue LED lights take minimal power and allow me to choose between putting almost all of the charge power into my charging device when I go out for a walk, or having several devices plugged in at a time.My laptop's USB ports are largely broken, and there's only one of them. This USB hub allows me to plug in an extra keyboard and mouse, because the shoddy quality of the Alienware keyboard the laptop came with meant that its keys have largely fallen off. I have had no choice but to find a USB hub, such as this one, when it comes to charging. I've used several brands of USB hub, and this is absolutely the best one I can find.I have, thus, given it TWO stars for cable length. Its cable is actually slightly larger than normal for USB hubs, meaning I don't need to worry as much about bumping it when I move my hands around the desk. It's really quite generous in that respect. However, even long for a USB hub is very short for a camera, which somehow the algorithm believes this is. As a camera, the charge cable is far too small. Once again, however, you need not worry, because it won't actually keep its charge anyway.I'm sorry to say that I am cannot in good conscience approve of the camera I was provided. However, since the page I bought it was labeled a USB extender port, and it is 100% the best one of those I have ever seen, sturdier than most, sticking effectively in the port on my laptop that most other things jiggle out of, that's not really that much of a disappointment.If you are looking for a digital camera, look elsewhere. This is not a digital camera. However, if you want a USB port, I cannot possibly recommend it highly enough. This is a miracle, and if it ever breaks just from overuse from how much I am carrying it around and such, I fully intend to replace it with another of the same brand. You can't get a better 4-port USB port, a fact which, I hope, will somewhat soften the blow to anyone who expected a camera.Five stars to the product, and one star to whatever idiot made Amazon's product recognition algorithms.
title: Worst Camera Ever, But Has Other Uses

author: Rachel McGrath
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
review_content: The product does what it says it'll do mostly. I use it to connect peripherals and not to charge so I can't attest to charging speed. Cord length is short but I just taped it to the top of my desktop. I had the product for roughly 2 years and like another review mentioned, I kept getting the disconnect and reconnect sound. The hub would randomly stop working and then after a few seconds would work again. I contacted Sabrent directly and they sent me a new unit even though my warranty expired. A slight caveat is they sent me the USB 2.0 version instead of the 3.0 version that I purchased. Overall, for the price it isn't horrible, thought next time, I'll probably go with a different hub from Sabrent.
title: Decent product, great customer service

author: JustChillin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2019
review_content: I was looking for something that would allow me to add additional USB 2.0 ports to my laptop and this was just what I needed.  It gives me 4 additional ports and the ability to selectively turn ports on/off is a nice bonus feature.  When a port is turned on, there is a blue led background light to let you know that port is enabled.  So far I have attached three devices to the hub and everything worked as expected.  I use this mostly for a USB mouse receiver and a separate USB mouse/keyboard receiver, but having the two additional ports open is a bonus.  I also have a Type C hub that I use for portable hard drives, and with everything connected I have never had any issues with any of the devices.  If you want to expand your USB 2.0 ports, this does the job nicely.
title: Gives me 4 more USB 2.0 ports for my laptop

author: JUST4U
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2017
review_content: I bought two of these, hoping to use it to enjoy my Chromcast and the LED back light for my Sony Bravia in my living room and bedroom.  I cannot tell if that's this UBS hub that's doing it or the LED light, but I cannot use the Chromcast and LED light at the same time.  I like to watch youtube videos on my large screen TV using Chromcast, but when I watch it in the dark I needed the back light to reduce my eye strain. When I turn on the light (push the button on the hub) my Chromcast will go on for about a minute, then lose its casting ability to quickly switch back to my laptop screen. I tried again and again to confirm that.  When I turn off the backlit LED light I can cast the video again on the TV, but I have to watch it in the dark. I am not sure if that has to do with the hub's capacity issue or not, but it really disappointed me. There are 4 slots on the hub but I cannot even imagine it an handle all 4 uses at the same time after failed on just 2.  I now watch TV shows in the dark with beautiful back light, but Amazon video or Youtube video in the bright room without back light. If the seller reads my review, please give me advice if that's normal or not.
title: 4 slots, but cant use more than 1 at a time??

author: Stormy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2019
review_content: For some reason, most of my laptops (I have 3) only come with 1-2 USB ports, which is really frustrating considering I need to use a wireless mouse/mic/camera/SD reader etc. There are never enough ports, so I decided to buy this affordable hub as a way to simplify my work and I am so glad I did. I even bought more hubs for my desktops because I love the feature of being able to shut off certain devices with the push of a button. I think the cord could be a little bit longer, but I really can't complain, the device works great!
title: I think EVERYONE with a laptop should buy one of these bad boys

author: Jennifer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2020
review_content: This USB hub is super. It's much smaller than I thought it would be (hadn't bothered to check dimensions) & that is great since I definitely don't need anything else taking up space on my desk. The cord is extremely short though. This is not any problem for me because I'm using it with a KVM that it sits right on top of - it's actually ideal for me. However, If I was trying to use this with another set up I might need an adapter just to get more length. I would recommend checking the cord length before ordering if that will be of any concern. I'm very happy with this purchase!
title: Works great, very short cord though

author: Jos
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2015
review_content: I bought this to go with my Surface Pro 3 as the 3 only has 1 USB port. This hub has several features going for it but two HUGE drawbacks, the cable length and power available. I love the blue LED backlighting that shows which ports are active and I love being able to activate and de-activate a port with the push of a button. However, you can't overlook the fact that the attached USB cord is WAY TO SHORT. It might be 8 inches long, maybe. That's far to short to be of much use unless you run wireless USB devices which I fortunately do. Otherwise, you're hosed. This just screams the company is to cheap to make a 2 foot or 3 foot USB cord which might cost them another 80 cents worth of wiring and coating. Minus one star for the absurdly short USB cord. Minus a second star for the fact that all of the power for this hub comes through the one attached USB cable. Being of a technical background myself, I knew this would cause issues but opted to try it anyways. Long story short, good luck power 4 USB devices at once. You'll need it. Powering a spinning hard drive along with a mouse and keyboard, you might as well forget about that. You might get away with a SSD but that's going to be cutting it close still. I mean, how did the developers not know this would be an issue? They had to but instead, opted for the cheap way out. Overall, I would pass this hub by in a heartbeat if I had to choose again.
title: Cool little gadget minus 2 HUGE problems.

author: Sam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2020
review_content: It's like everything about this hub was shrunk except the USB connectors. The four sockets are very (and unnecessarily) close together. I have lots of USB devices, but no four of them can be used at once, there just isn't enough room. The 10-inch cable is also unnecessarily short, and won't reach from any of my computer's USB ports to the top of the computer. Luckily I had a USB extension cable. Surely it wouldn't break the bank to make the internal board an inch longer, and the cable another foot longer. Since it's USB 2.0, it's not really very good for larger USB drives, but it's fine for slow things like keyboard, mouse, or USB lamps.
title: Tight squeeze

author: Jaguar Skies
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 17, 2016
review_content: I purchased this 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub with Individual Power Switches & LEDs (Black) almost two years ago and it still works great. Others have mentioned in their reviews that they ran into some issues with it disconnecting their external hard drives while in use. Fortunately, I can say that although I have had this happened to me before with this device, it has only happened once or twice in the whole time I've had it. The one or two times it has disconnected or improperly ejected my drive was when I either plugged or unplugged something else into the 4-Port Hub (I believe it was during a transfer, so it seems that the connection was disrupted from the additional source added or being taken away), or when I turned pressed or depressed one of the buttons to cut power to that USB port.Because I cited either of these activities as disrupting the connection to my external drive, I just do not mess with the on/off port buttons or plug/unplug anything during a transfer just as a precaution. (Note: the drive does not disconnect every single time that things are plugged/unplugged or the button for a port is pushed, I can usually use it like normal even when my external is connected. The drive has only disconnected due to this activity those very few times mentioned).I like the ability to "turn off" the connection to specific ports by using the buttons so certain drives though ejected are "unplugged."I have a MacBook Pro so having additional USB ports was a must with only two available on my computer. I would definitely recommend this product to a friend. The price is extremely good too considering the use I've gotten out of it thus far.
title: 0 Hub with Individual Power Switches & LEDs (Black) almost two years ago and it still works great. Others have mentioned in thei

author: Sarah Lewis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2019
review_content: I bought this hub to extend the USB capabilities of my new Windows PC. I like that even if I don't want to unplug it entirely, I can turn off the lights for sleeping (my office doubles as our guest room). author: Curtis S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2019
review_content: If my review headline makes sense to you, this will work perfectly for that particular use case.  It also is pretty small and was easy to conceal.I've used Velcro to mount this on the underside of my Tesla Model 3's phone charging/holding area. With the update that brought the dashcam feature, one port had to be taken by the USB thumb drive used to store the video. So this allows me to still have the integrated dashcam setup, but still have the charging cable on both sides.The ability to enable/disable each port with a physical hardware switch is quite nice. author: JJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2018
review_content: I have had this product for a month+ now and it works GREAT!  For the price, this device is one of my top 10 life purchases. (my 6+ foot Russell Westbrook [OKC Thunder] Fathead vinyl wall decal is another) This device is so convenient and easy to use. This is one of those devices that makes so much sense!I purchased this product for my Pioneer A/V Receiver, that has a usb port, so my wife and I could listen to the different genres of music we like at the press of a bottom.  For example, I like a mixture of rock, country and r&b. My wife, mainly, likes r&b. I also purchased some SanDisk Cruzer Fit flash drives which fit perfectly in this hub. Each flash drive stores the different genres of music.Things to remember:-Ports are close together, so if your flash drives are normal size or bigger, then you may, only, be able to use 2 or 3 of the ports.-When you first insert your flash drive, for the first time, be extremely carful not to force or shove it into the port; there are tiny contact pins in the ports that will bend if not inserted gently and straight. ( I speak from experience...this is my second one.) After the first insertion, I pull out and insert the flash drives normally.
title: For the price, this device is one of my top 10 life purchases.

author: Hyouten
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2016
review_content: My fiance's computer is about five or six years old, with about four USB ports total. Two of them were USB 3.0 and only read our 2.0 devices half the time. The other two are USB 2.0, but one of them stopped working.When I bought him a new wired keyboard and mouse, the lack of USB ports quickly because a problem. My brother suggested getting a hub, and after searching around I decided to go with this brand.I was initially worried about the quality in regards to price, but boy was I wrong. This little item turned out to be the perfect solution to his lack of functioning USB ports. Each port on this hub has an on/off switch, so you only draw power out of the port when you need it. Each switch has blue LEDs underneath so it's easy to see even in the dark. The switches are also perfect for giving the system time to recognize the devices one at a time. And most of all, this item's small size is perfect for travelling. He always has this hub in his computer backpack.I'm not sure about the longevity of this item if it's plugged in to the computer all the time with several devices tethered to it. My fiance unplugs the hub every time he's not using the keyboard and mouse to reduce strain on the computer. Though even with the frequent plug-unplug of this hub, it still works perfectly.If you want a central spot to plug in your devices, or need to maximize your only remaining port, get this hub.

author: R. Suzuki
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2020
review_content: This was smaller than I expected but that was a plus, very compact design that still does the job. Delivered prompted and in good condition from seller.

author: Mike S,
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2018
review_content: Its a very nice item.  Seems to be well made although I have only been using it for a short time. author: Jack from WV
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2020

The orientation is nice (all of the USB plugs are on one edge). I can easily have both of my monitors plugged in and my mouse and keyboard while freeing up the other two USB ports on my laptop. Worth every penny.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2017
review_content: I bought this because I needed a hub that would charge multiple phones at once, & it doesn't even charge one phone. author: dlcannon

author: Spirit the Magician
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2016
review_content: Product shipped on-time, and works perfectly ...as a simply technique...  to conncet FOUR (yes, 4x) 2-Tera-Byte, Western Digital, 2TB "My Book Desktop External Hard Drives", to a "Dish Network" receiver/descrambler/demodulator - result?  8-Tera-Bytes of external, movie storage (that's space for about 2,000 to 2,500 HDTV events!  Of importance: the Dish Network receiver "box" allows a user to connect only 1x USB-drive at a time.  The trick to use this idea?  Power-"OFF" the receiver box, before selecting any given USB-drive (remember: only one at a time), then Power-"ON" the box again.  It's safe, sure - and it works!  Note:  the external DVR drives used with Dish Network [MUST] have their own power supply - so, I also bought a power-strip for transformers (the transformers are turned 90-degrees, and there's a surge-suppressor), which allows all FOUR (4) external drives to remain powered-up.  This USB hub allows the user to "Select" (connect), just ONE external drive at a time.  Doing so, doesn't damage anything, and the connection methods respects the Dish Network warranty of your receiver box.  ;-)  Enjoy!
title: -) Enjoy!

author: A. Moore
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2019
review_content: I have purchased more than ten of these little hubs over the years and loved them. They have been my go to hub for a number of needs. But I just bought a new one and was sorely disappointed when I opened the box. They used to have a high quality cable with a thick, robust housing sleeve...close to  1/4" thick. This new one is barely an 1/8" and very flimsy. I don't think it will last long at all. I don't think it is durable enough for travel purposes. So sad to see another company ruin a perfectly good product to save a few pennies. I would have rather paid the difference to get a quality product. Now I will have to find another go-to USB hub.
title: Used to be a great product. Now?

author: Nemo-Nova
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 12, 2016
review_content: First I ordered a 3.0 USB Hub.  I now use it on a PC and I'm very happy with it.  But I wanted to share my particular case in the hope this will helps others....Originally, I wanted to attach a K400 keyboard to an Nvidia Shield TV.  I found out (after long research, buried deep in [Nvidia] forums) that a 3.0 USB will not work to drive the K400 keyboard.  To use the K400, you *must* connect a 2.0 USB.So then I got the Sabrent 2.0 Hub.  I first attached the 2.0 Sabrent to my PC, loaded the Logitech Unifying software and it found the keyboard right away.So, it all worked out, but not before a lot of digging and research.  One feature that I really like about both of these hubs is the switches.  You can turn devices ON or OFF by simply using a switch.  I think that is so cool and very handy.  You might have an external drive that doesn't need to be on 24/7 constantly (I do), so that comes in real handy.  These Sabrent hubs do everything I need them to do.The Sabrent 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub saved the day!!  And I like the Sabrent 3.0 USB as well. I put it to good use on my PC.Thank you Sabrent! I will most definitely be buying gear from you again!
title: First I ordered a 3.0 USB Hub. ...

author: Jessica
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2019
review_content: I love the idea behind this and the price was great, but it is not worth the price because it is as cheaply made as it is to purchase... I bought one previously somewhere else and only 3 of the 4 ports worked on it (and I had bought it for my son) so I decided to purchase one of these for myself.  The one I got all of the lights shine blue when you plug it in and it appears to be working great until you go to use the USB - none of the ports charged my phone or did anything when I attempted. I made sure they were turned on and the ligths were on and I tried multiple different sources to rule out each USB port- all 4 did not work - returning product and won't be attempting another purchase.
title: Did not work, sending back

author: Adorios
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: My new computer didn't have enough conveniently placed USB ports, so I use this to supplement it.  It's great for that.  I especially appreciate the ability to toggle the things plugged in on and off.  It makes it very easy to switch between a couple of different modes in my computer without having to fiddle with what's plugged in.I do wish the cord was maybe 6" longer so it could sit comfortably on top of my computer without the cord being stretched taught and prone to sliding.
title: The buttons are appreciated

author: willisota
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2016
review_content: I absolutely love this USB hub. I work from home, and many meetings are handled through my Mac. As part of our privacy policy, I have to use headphones for these, since private customer information may be discussed.Previously, I used the ports on the aluminum full sized keyboard that came with my Mac. Since that keyboard finally died, I replaced it with another one that did not include the two USB ports. I was a little annoyed at first, since trying to fumble to plug the headphones in for meetings behind the mac was somewhat difficult. Additionally, needing to plug and unplug my iOS devices to accommodate this left me unimpressed, as well as having to sometimes juggle my USB stick when I needed headphones, and the iPod.This wasn't much of an issue when I could plug in to the keyboard, but behind the mac was just a pain.This USB hub was the PERFECT answer. In addition to giving me plenty of extra USB ports, the switching feature means I can leave my headset plugged in full time. I just press the button to have it go live for meetings, then go back to internal mic/speakers by turning off the port. Super Simple! The blue power indicators for each port are very nice, without being overpowering.I am looking to purchase a few more for my PC, and my family's PC's as well (including one with a wall adapter, for my power hungry devices)
title: Easy to use, and so convenient.

author: Curiel
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2020
review_content: This has survived over five spills and is incredibly convenient for my poorly designed HP pavilions USB port only located under the monitor, completely out of view, and impossible to use with any USB attachment longer than 2 cm (basically any USB) this little guy doesnt save superior bus ports (no midi or usbmidi) but it does a great job with devices requiring drivers, data sticks to transfer files, phone connections, android bridge debugging software etc. A+
title: Cute little high functioning device with individual on off buttons

author: Orion
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2019
review_content: Works for playstation classic with bleemsync to allow you to play two player by plugging both controllers to this hub into port number 1
title: Works on playstation classic

author: Caerbannog
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2015
review_content: This hub is a piece of junk.  I connected devices to it that didn't require bus powering and these devices would constantly disconnect from my system.  I can't sustain a successful connection with any of my devices and my computer using this hub.  I wish I had never purchased it.  It is super cheap, and you get what you pay for.  Too cheap for me to bother returning it.  Bummer.[UPDATE Sept 7, 2015]  Andrew from Sabrent contacted me (on his own initiative, I might add - and solely because he saw this Amazon review) and followed up by sending out a replacement unit to me, including an AC adapter (which wasn't even part of my initial purchase).  The replacement USB hub works just fine.  Thanks very much Andrew!  Also, to clarify, attached to the older (failed) unit was in the simplest scenario of just one device - a PNY USB flash thumb drive which draws very little current - and even with just that one device the drive would erratically attach and detach constantly (while it was plugged in) which made it basically impossible to access the thumb drive in any reliable way.  This doesn't happen with the new hub - it maintains the connection (so far).So I have to say that I'm very impressed with Sabrent's proactive support.  It's unusual, and speaks highly of them.  Given this experience, I would purchase future products from Sabrent.
title: A Sad Story Made Happy by Andrew at Sabrent Support

author: Emma
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2020
review_content: After getting a monitor/laptop stand for my sit-stand desk, I found that two of my laptop USB ports were covered by the clips that held the laptop in place. I ordered this USB hub to remedy that problem. It was perfect for that - I have my camera, wireless mouse/keyboard and headset plugged into it, and all work perfectly. What I didn’t realize is how helpful the “on/off” buttons would be! I used to need to plug-in or unplug whenever I wanted to switch between using my headset or using my laptop mic/speakers. Now, all I have to do is push a button to turn the headset on or off! So much better! I used strong 3M adhesive to attach the hub to the bottom of the laptop platform on the monitor/laptop stand. I couldn’t be happier with this little gadget!
title: On/Off buttons are more helpful than I realized!

author: Robert R.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2015
review_content: I really like this switch.  It has an input for a power adapter, which I supplied. (There seems to be some confusion about this is the Q&A answers.)  It allows me to power or unpower individual devices (e.g., my Arduino processors, backup disk drives) as desired, without plugging/unplugging USB cables.  I can also charge my phone or GPS, or whatever with it.The paragraph above is actually from my review of the USB2.0 version of this hub.  I liked it so well I ordered the 3.0 version (with power supply) for my new machine with USB 3.0 ports.  I now have it plugged into my Dynadoc U3.0 docking station so I can leave a couple of HDDs and a flash drive plugged in and take them on- or off-line using the appropriate switch if  I don't forget to eject them first :-)I initially had two problems: 1. I didn't plug the power supply into my power strip - the hub will drive flash drives, but won't supply enough power to handle a disk drive.  It easily handled two HDDs when I plugged in the power supply.  Duh.2. At one point, I ejected all (3) devices on the hub (a flash drive and 2 HDDs), turned off the corresponding switches, then tried to bring one of the devices back on line by turning on it's switch.  The computer didn't recognize the presence of the device.  I managed to clear this condition by unplugging the huib from the docking station, and reinserting it.  After this, each device would come up, and I could eject them all (and power them down), and could bring them online again by pushing the appropriate switch.  I haven't seen the problem since.
title: I really like this device

author: EWS Review
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2020
review_content: I love this product I am still using it now. This product solve problems of having only a few functioning usb port on your computer, whether due to old system or due to big tech company limiting usb ports to exploit their customers. The hub comes with 4 available ports. I love that you can toggle each port on and off, giving you control of what device you want to connect or disconnect to the hub and the computer. The usb draws power from your computer so based on my experience, it works better when connected to USB 2.0 or 3.0 ports. I am satisfied with this product.
title: Works best with USB 2.0 or 3.0

author: A. Pava
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2020
review_content: Bought this specifically to add my Apple iPhone. Says it works with Apple, but after receiving and trying it does not. If you then look into the questions, it's clear it can be used with some Apple products but does not charge Apple products. That should be a heck of a lot clearer in the description. Seems to work with other items, so it was inexpensive and I can use it elsewhere, but beware if you are wanting to use this with your iPhone/iPad.
title: Doesn't charge iPhone

author: John Smith
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review_content: This review is for the Sabrent 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub with Individual LED lit Power Switches (HB-UMLS).So look carefully, it is USB 2.0 not 3.0, so if you need speed, forget it. But it's perfect for my use case, where I have multiple wireless dongles for keyboards and mice that I attach to the hub. It's nice to be able to switch them on/off individually and the hub lets me quickly switch from using one computer to another. And at least when I bought it, it was cheaper than other options.
title: Value for money, depending on your use case

author: J. Rust
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
review_content: First of all, I really do like the design of this hub, but over the years of using it, I definitely have had some problems with it.The switches are awesome. I use them to turn on and off USB headphones and other devices. But the problem isn't with the design, its with the electronics part.I used to have a mini-fridge in the same room as my computer using this hub. EVERY time the compressor would kick on, all of the devices work disconnect and reconnect. Every time!After moving to a room without a fridge, the problem went away.... until recently. Now it seems that after 3 years, the Hub is now starting to kick the bucket. The switches still work, but my computer now will now only recognize the devices somewhat, and it seems like it is random ports that do not work now. Mind you, I haven't changed anything about my setup for months without issues, but now it seems to be having problems.Overall I love the design of this hub and how easy it is to turn ports on and off, but it has always been somewhat unreliable depending on what is around it, but it has lasted a decent amount of time for the price. Depending on what you need, this may work, but I will be spending a little bit more money on my replacement.
title: ISSUES with USB 2 Hub!

author: Spastik Kolon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2016
review_content: This product took some getting used to. I originally thought it was broken but what I did not realize is that this product is not "plug and play." I have a surface pro 3 and it only came with one USB port. I use a USB Mouse because it's easier to use and I have my USB with all the stored documents. Not to mention, I also have my back up 1TB hard drive. At any given moment, I may need all three on at the same time. Sometimes I hook up speakers via USB as well. This device not only allows me to have all four plugged in at the same time, but allows me to switch on and off the device I am not using without going through wires and set. I literally set all my devices once and all I have to do is plug in this device instead of several other devices. So, if I am listening to music, I press the switch for USB and USB back up drive to off, leave mouse and speakers on. If I'm working from home, I leave everything but the speakers on. If I'm on skype or havine a virtual meeting for work, everything is on! This device can handle multiple devices without overheating or becoming dysfunctional! Great product!
title: Great Product!

author: Dandelion
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2017
review_content: CONVENIENT AND EASY TO USE:I have a Surface Pro with only one USB port.  I am so glad I bought this 4-port USB hub!  I can attach my printer, my 10-key pad, and an external hard-drive and leave it plugged in instead of having to keep switching them out.  The buttons are also convenient.  When I want to eject my external hard-drive from my computer, I can simply click the button to turn off that port after ejecting it.  My external hard-drive can still be attached physically, but its port is turned off.SMALL IMPROVEMENT SUGGESTION:The only thing I would like to see different about this product is a longer cord.  I was aware of the length at the time of purchase .  But it would help if it was just a bit longer by a few more inches.OVERALL:I would buy this product again.
title: Great accessory, especially for devices with just one USB port.

author: Lucia Hale
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2020
review_content: With light use, this USB hub has all of a sudden stopped working. Whenever it's connected now, it will connect and disconnect every two seconds, so whatever devices I have plugged in do not function as intended. The USB hub I bought at Staples years ago still works and is much more reliant than this waste of money. I would return it if I could.
title: stopped working after only two months

author: Rosque E.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2019
review_content: I started out using a 32GB thumb drive (USB) and partitioned it to separate MP3s and for Tesla Dashcam, it worked fine but I noticed some quality issues and a few bugs while screening through dashcam videos. I read that a USB hub will work and found several Tesla owners giving this a high rating. It works as intended and I am able to charge my phone, connect two thumb drives, 32GB & 16GB, for music and dashcam, and best of all I can use the Logitech gamepad F310. I do like the feature of disabling the USB ports and the only time I do that is when removing the video drive.
title: Works with Model 3 2018

author: Adam
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2019
review_content: I use this with my laptop that only has 1 working USB port. I can now charge my phone, use my mouse, control an arduino, and plug in my external hard drive all at once. I really like the buttons that allow you turn turn off and on the ports. They supply a satisfying click and light up when they're on. I haven't noticed any slower speeds or heating up when using all four ports. It's lightweight and small so it's easy to carry with you to anywhere you use a laptop. If you feel like you don't have enough USB ports and do not want to spend a significant amount of money I would recommend this one.
title: Functions as desired

author: reebohyeah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 27, 2018
review_content: These hubs are merely okay at best.  It is partly my fault for not paying attention to detail in the description.  I was expecting powered USB 2.0 hubs with switches.  I had previously ordered the USB 3.0 versions with the switches, but needed a couple of USB 2.0 hubs.  I figured this was from the same company and BAM I would be done.  It is okay, I do not blame the company for my laziness.  I am sure I will find uses for these hubs.  They work as intended, but not exactly what I needed.  The company was insistent on me giving a review, so I am giving one.  For anyone interested in these hubs, please note.....these are NOT powered hubs.  They only get power from the USB port that it plugs into, which is never enough in most cases.
title: They work, but they are not power hubs

author: George Piazza
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2018
review_content: Plugged it in and it worked great. The individual power buttons are handy for controlling the amount of power drawn from the computer's USB bus.My only (very minor) complaint is that the cable is very short. Probably good for a laptop, but less convenient for a big desktop computer. If you plan to place the hub any distance from the computer, you will need a USB extension cable. I am using one to place the hub on my desk and it works great. Still 5 stars for value.If you only need a few extra ports & aren't looking for fast charging, the Sabrent is a great low cost option.If you are running several devices that draw a lot of power, if you need more than 4 ports or you want USB fast charging, you will have to spring for something more expensive with its own power supply.
title: Excellent performance and value
verified: for USB devices with modest power draw

author: Phil
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
review_content: I've used Sabrent  products before and have been impressed with the quality versus price. When I was searching for USB hubs to try to get some of the clutter off my desk and move it up to a shelf, mainly a bunch of external hard drives that I use for storage , I happened to find this little gem which was just what I was looking for.Since everything I was going to Plug-in to it is self-powered this is exactly what I needed, small, individual switches, solid construction, and the lights were just a nice extra touch.Construction is good, USB connections fit tightly as they should, and so far it's performed very well. For the price of this unit I don't think you can expect NASA quality switches, but they certainly seem adequate for the job.I plan on buying another one just to have it around for the next need that arises if you need a hub that's not powered then you can't beat this one
title: For quality and price, can't be beat

author: pStove
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2016
review_content: Love it.  Small, lightweight, portable for my laptop used for recording music.  My laptop has limited USB ports and I'm already using a Rosewill  USB 2.0 quad hub but it didn't provide individual on/off buttons. I'm running a usb mouse, usb external DVD writer and a usb midi keyboard. The only remaining port on my laptop provided bus power, for charging devices, even when the laptop was turned off.  I want the bus powered peripherals to shut down when laptop shuts down. Chained the Rosewill hub into port 1 so I only need to click one button to turn off the peripherals.  My usb mouse adapter was in the original hub so i moved that over to one of the open Sabrent ports so i can operate the laptop when not using laptop for recording/mixing.  so far so good.  My only disappointment is with myself for not purchasing the USB 3.0 hub version since my port is 3.0.  Although my current peripherals are USB 1.1 or 2.0,  the upgraded model would have provided more flexibility.  current model holding it's own and no complaints with the product itself.
title: Small, lightweight, portable for my laptop

author: Justadude
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2016
review_content: We have all been there, standing in the aisles of the place where you are supposed to find the best of buys, staring at the glorious peg hooks filled with USB hubs ranging from $15 and all all the up to $100 plus. I was literally there when I decided to pull out my phone and check Amazon for the same thing I was looking at (not exact same brand but same device) and found this little gem. The first thing you should notice is the size of the chord that connects the hub to the usb on your pc or laptop. Notice it looks nice and long. I didn't get out a tape measure but my guess is at least a foot long. The one is the other mentioned store for twice the price was about 2 inches maybe. Doesn't sound like an issue until you go to plug 4 chords into it. The nice long chord on this one gives you plenty of room to set it on something rather that just leave it hang from your desktop or crowd your lap top so much you cant move it. It is fast as well, takes about 7 seconds for windows to recognize the device once you hit the power button. Which by the way is a really nice feature. A file gets locked and you need to disconnect and reconnect quickly it is literally a push of a button. All and all this is a great little usb hub and I am very happy with my purchase.
title: Size matters..... But so does price and quality. Great news is this has both.

author: Brendon
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2020
review_content: This model doesnt have an AC adapter , meaning it wont charge phones or any device.Works great when using USB's for storage or file transfers. The individual power switches are very useful.The lights are isolated well enough to very easily distinguish which ones are on, and which ones are off. And, the switches are tactile and makes a quiet clicking noise when turning it on or off.Fast speeds , reliable , durable. Thick wire and insulation cover , but thin profile makes it perfect for travel
title: Not for charging devices. Works perfectly

author: W. Ellison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2016
review_content: Small enough to stash in a laptop bag or conceal in a PC build.  The latter is actually why I bought this hub: to use with a few wireless dongles to add concealed Bluetooth and Logitech Unifying to my gaming PC.  Combined with the NZXT IU01 internal USB hub, this Sabrent hub works well with the aforesaid dongles and works with any OS.  I took a couple of Command strips and stuck it to the front of my case (NZXT H440) behind the vanity shroud and ran the wire inside through a conveniently placed hole to plug it into the IU01 board.  That's it: that's all it takes.  Now I get built-in Bluetooth and Unifying with essentially no signal loss.  I like the individual power buttons -- I can disable the ports I don't need, hopefully reducing overall power draw.Probably far enough off the spec sheets to confuse the guys (and gals) at Sabrent, but I like it. :-)
title: A good option, curiously, for case modders.

author: cavedave
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2020
review_content: This is a well-designed and practical way to add USB ports to a notebook. The product is packaged nicely and sealed. Just understand that it is for docking - NOT for charging. Basically, it's like an extension cord. That's it. There is another, more expensive model that docks AND charges. So, don't be hasty when ordering. If you just want to add USB ports to your notebook or laptop, you can't beat this unit for functionality or price!
title: Nicely Designed, Priced Right!

author: Mark J.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2020
review_content: I needed additional ports with switches for my old Vista OS lab computer and these work great. I wish they had a 7 or 10 port version but I added a second 4-port and both seem to work fine. The buttons can be sticky when depressing on/off but not a big deal. The main USB lead to the PC is VERY short (6" or so), but that worked fine for me. I've tried a few other switchable USB hubs from other manufacturers and the quality was terrible. I recommend these from Sabrent.
title: Great for USB 2.0 on Vista and added switches

author: Kelli
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2015
review_content: I purchased this product to use with a laptop, the laptop only has 2 USB ports, and when some of the keys stopped working, I hooked up a desktop keyboard to it, and I use a USB mouse on it, so that took my 2 spots up. I'd have to unplug the mouse to plug in the USB charger for my phone, or camera, and that was just getting annoying. I didn't want to spend a ton of money on a USB huh, when I came across this one I read the reviews, some were good some where bad. But I went with it anyway, I figured for the price, it wouldn't break my bank to give it a try for myself.I'm very happy I chose this product, Yes it has a short cord, but that is not a problem if its used on a laptop, OR the front area of most towers, I also like that it has individual on/off buttons for each USB slot, so that way If I have my Phone docking station in one, and my USB cord for my camera in one, but am not using those atm just keeping them plugged in (so I don't misplace them) I can shut those 2 sources off and only keep the ones I am using turned on.I will be recommending this product to family and friends who are in need of extra USB ports. It's made nicely, it doesn't feel cheap or flimsy , which I did expect it would for the price.
title: Love finally having extra USB ports

author: Tia
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2020
review_content: I bought two one for me and the other for my son and we love it.  My son uses to work 3-4 flash drives at a time and really likes that there is enough space for each one and can use at the same time. I bought it because I have to work at home and need 2 monitors for my laptop that only has 2 USB ports  Those ports are being used for the wireless keyboard/mouse and the other for my headphone, so definitely needed this which works great for the set up!
title: Works Great

author: healthnut
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2020
review_content: It is just what I needed, and at a great price!  My macbook only has two USB outlets and these days, with all the Zoom for work, classes, etc., it became necessary to have more than two items plugged in at a time - external microphone, cooling pad for my older computer, the printer, ring light, .....  Now I don't have to unplug things, and that is a welcome help.  I like that I can turn each slot on of off.
title: Great little gadget

author: jchugo
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 16, 2016
review_content: Great product for anyone that is struggling with the lack of USB Ports on their current machines.  I am liking the way you can turn the ports on and off as needed.  The buttons have lighting as well, making it easy to discern whether or not the port is on or off.  Nothing really too complicated about this product, you can just plug it into your existing USB port and plug your other items into it (no setup required).  Keep in mind this is a 2.0 Hub and now newer electronics are coming out with the 3.0 compatibility so order as required.Shipping was Prime shipping and super fast... since the item was small it came in a padded envelope and fit in my condo buildings mailbox system easily.  No damages and wrapped in it's blister plastic.  Probably the most dangerous part for me was cutting it out of that stuff since I always feel like the rigid plastic tends to cut me when I'm trying to get into the packaging, but no blood spilled on this occassion.
title: Quick, Easy, and Great!

author: Shannon OHare
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2018
review_content: I have a laptop with only 3 USB ports, but when I have my fan, my portable mouse, my external hard-drive, that's three spots right there. Sometimes In need to plug my iPod in to charge it, or attach my phone to transfer files. I've noticed with the iPod it tends to not upload the album covers, and my external hard-drive doesn't quite fit the plug in's so I still manage to plug those two things into the laptop, but the portable mouse, the fan, and my phone all plug in nicely through this little 4 port USB port.This is my second purchase of this item because after owning the first one for a little over a year, the little white parts that the cords plug into fall out an the port it belonged to becomes unusable.
title: Decent solution for extra ports

author: Karen D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2019
review_content: This is exactly what I needed to extend my use of USB peripherals.  The cord length isn't long but adequate for my needs as I like to have the on-off switches close to my laptop anyway.  My only wish is that the length of the item was perhaps one inch longer giving a little more space between the USB ports for ease in installing or removing a USB cord.  I found it easier to leave the cords attached and just remove or switch the items that were charging since most use the same style of cord.  I love the light-up feature on each of the on/off buttons.
title: Very helpful

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2019

author: Paul Bollenbacher
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2018
review_content: I bought this 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub because my laptop only has two ports and I need to use one for my USB wireless mouse. (I do not like using the touch pad.) If I wanted to transfer info from one drive to another I either had to copy to my desktop and then to the other drive or disconnect my wireless mouse. While I am satisfied with this product, bit it does have both Pros and Cons that I will list here:Pros:• I can keep up to four flash drives connected to the hub without having to remove them once I’m done. I use only SanDisk flash drives, but other brands may be narrower and fit better. My solution was to use USB extension cables. Their plugs are narrow enough to fit between the flash drives.For me, the Pros out weigh the Cons. It allows me the convenience to have up to four flash drives connected and ready to turn on and use at a moment’s notice. I give it 4 stars.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2014
review_content: I have a couple Sabrent USB switched hubs.  I run most everything through these because I can easily turn off and on the devices I want to use without having to un/plug them. author: Ralph Furlong
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2013
review_content: I needed to add a couple of extra USB 2.0 ports to a small desktop and thought I would give this product a try.  Here is what I liked:  1.  Inexpensive.  2.  Four ports (three more than you started with since you use one port to plug this into) that can each be turned off by pressing the button above the port.  When the port is enabled (powered) there is a blue LED that lights.  You can turn each port on or off independently of the other ports.  3.  Small, this is a very compact design.What I did not like as much:  1.  This is not a robust hub!  The construction is such that with care it should perform well.  It will NOT stand up to an abusive environment!  2.  VERY short connector cord (4 inches).  3.  No mounting provisions.I wound up using double stick tape to attach this device to the back of my computer.  This keeps it out of harms way.  I also put stress relief on all cables attaching to this so that they would not put undue stress on the hub.  Using it in this way, the device performs exactly what I was looking for.  I use this to connect the keyboard, mouse, and printer.  None of those devices has a large current draw.  This is important because this device does NOT have a separate power supply and you are therefore depending upon the original port you connected to for all power to all devices on this hub.Considering the price and as long as you remember the limitations that I mentioned, this hub performs well for the price you are paying for it.

review_content: Self-bussing USB hub users often experience two contradictory qualities: it is highly convenient to have a small hub that will run on self-bussing computer power; AND the hubs often don't perform very well. Another great feature is the ability to easily turn the individual ports on the hub on and off with the push of a button.  A clear blue light indicates whether the hub is on or off. I also run up and down stairs with my computer a couple of times a day to go from film studio to living room to home office, and the hub has strong connections and a well-build but light design that easily travels with me without disconnecting my portable hard drives. review_content: Awesome little hub that works very well.  The leds on top let you know which port is on and which is off.  No more powering down things to unplug them, just click the button on top.  Brilliant design.What you don't know about hubs:Hubs used to be used in networks as the main connection point for computers to talk to one another.  Some people probably still use them at times.  This is fine until you get too many computers talking to each other.  A hub is stupid.  It will send communication it receives to every port attached - even if the port doesn't need it.  For networks, this is terrible because so much little talk is being transmitted and received across different computers.  It will slow down immensely.A USB 2.0 hub is no different.  It's sending the data to every port.  With this having the ability to turn off the ports not being used, it speeds up the communication.  I like that I can keep some things plugged in and just turn them off when they are not needed.  The speed does go up, but it's also handy not seeing those things pop up in my computer window when I'm working.Yes, I recommend this hub - it looks great and works great

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2013
review_content: Someone commented on a switch being improper disconnect, but proper Plug nPlay devices wont get improper plug warnings. If you unplug and the drive wasnt ready, youre safer to plug the same item back in; the danger is to plug a different directory into that same port, and then from RAM it writes the former directory onto the new different drive. Computers have only so much memory for directories, and once they max, they will drop a drive from your hub to load the next drive up of your hub. I learned this with a ten port USB hub. This maxing the directory memory of your computer will crash one directory to load up the next directory. And in my case twice i lost a WD Passport Tera drive permanantly because of too much directory Gigs. (Yes, i did swap a drive, and it tried to claim the new drive was the former one plugged in.) So the push-button off is a must for safely having four Tera drives connected. The off-on buttons is a must for USB hubs. WAIT until you hear the computer beep of USB connect or USB drop. I wont buy a USB hub anymore without switches. They were formerly expensive and i was being tight and cheap. I wont buy a switchless ten hub anymore, anybody want mine for free?
title: Push-Button USB a MUST to avoid USB crashes

author: general bonkers
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 2, 2016
review_content: This thing doesn't do a fantastic job on its own. USB 1~2 standards dictate that a unit can deliver 100mA of current on average, and up to 500mA of current if the unit sends a request, and the host allows it. Now downstream if you have no power for your USB hub, you can only deliver 100mA per USB slot. So if your devices are not playing nice you may have dropouts in the USB Hub. Adding a power supply would fix this, but the power jack on the side appears to be non-standard. If you want a USB hub, I suggest spending a bit more and finding one that is powered. You will have fewer problems.

I wrote back explaining that one of the ports were broken, but that it could have been my own fault. The seller immediately sent me a replacement and told me I could keep the defective hub as well. I couldn't be more satisfied with their customer service. This was a situation where it's possible--maybe even probable--that it was not their fault (I spent quite some time pondering the likelihood of a bent tooth in the port being a manufacturing error...), and without hesitation they sent me a replacement. They were customer-oriented and responsive.So far I've had zero issues with the hub aside from their being a bit tight for my Logitech usb drive (other drives less so). It is a great product at a great price point. Overall, I am 100% satisfied with the purchase and with the seller's customer service.
